sen.j: 坂上 田村麻呂（さかのうえ の たむらまろ）は、平安時代の武官である。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro is a military officer in the Heian period.
SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro was a military officer of the Heian period.
SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro was a military officer of the Heian period.

sen.j: 名は田村麿とも書く。
sen.e: His name Tamuramaro (田村麻呂) is also spelled '田村麿.'
His name Tamuramaro (田村麻呂) is also written '田村麿.'
His name Tamuramaro (田村麻呂) is also written '田村麿.'

sen.j: 正三位、大納言兼右近衛大将兵部卿。
sen.e: He was awarded the Shosammi rank and was appointed as the Chief Councilor of State and Hyobu-kyo (Chief of Hyobu) Ukon-e-no-Daisho.
He was awarded the Shosammi (Senior Third) rank and was appointed Chief Councilor of State, Commander of the Imperial Guards and Minister of War.
sen.cmt: Added "(Senior Third)"Deleted "as the"Moved "and"Added comma"Hyobu-kyo (Chief of Hyobu)"→"Minister of War""Ukon-e-no-Daisho"→"Commander of the Imperial Guards"
sen.e: He was awarded the Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank) and was appointed Dainagon (chief councilor of state), Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards) and Hyobukyo (Minister of Hyobusho Ministry of Military).
sen.cmt: 正三位→Shosanmi (Senior Third Rank)[用語集]大納言→Dainagon (Major Counselor)[用語集]右近衛大将→Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards)[用語集]兵部卿→Hyobukyo (Minister of Hyobusho Ministry of Military)[用語集]Dainagon (Major Counselor)→Dainagon (chief councilor of state)に変更しました。

sen.j: 勲二等。
sen.e: Kun-nito (Order of Merit).
Kun-nito (Order of Merit).
Kun-nito (Order of Second Class).
sen.cmt: 勲二等→Order of Second Class[用語集]

sen.j: 死後従二位を贈られた。
sen.e: He was posthumously awarded the Juni rank.
He was posthumously awarded the Juni (Junior Second) rank.
He was posthumously awarded the Junii (Junior Second Rank).
sen.cmt: 従二位→Junii (Junior Second Rank)[用語集]

sen.j: 中央で近衛府の武官として立ち、793年に陸奥国の蝦夷に対する戦争で大伴弟麻呂を補佐する副将軍の一人として功績を上げた。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro became known as a military officer in the Konoefu government office in Kyoto and achieved military success in the war against the Ezo people in Mutsu in 793 as one of the Vice Shoguns in OTOMO no Otomaro's army.

SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro came to notice as an officer in the Imperial Guards in Kyoto and achieved military success as one of the Vice Shoguns in OTOMO no Otomaro's army in the war against the Ezo people in Mutsu in 793.
sen.cmt: "became known"→"came to notice"Deleted "military""Konoefu government office"→"Imperial Guards"Moved "as one of the Vice Shoguns in OTOMO no Otomaro's army"- "Ezo" is OK but I wonder if "Emishi" wouldn't be better
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro came to notice as an officer in the Imperial Guards in Kyoto and achieved military success as one of the Vice Shoguns in OTOMO no Otomaro's army in the war against the Ezo people in Mutsu Province in 793.

sen.j: 弟麻呂の後任の征夷大将軍になって総指揮をとり、801年に敵対する蝦夷を討って降した。
sen.e: He succeeded to Otomaro as the Seii-Taishogun (Commander in Chief) and directed the government army, defeating the Ezo army in 801.
He succeeded Otomaro as the Seii-Taishogun (Commander in Chief) and directed the government army, defeating the Ezo army in 801.
sen.cmt: Deleted "to""Seii-Taishogun (Commander in Chief)"→"Shogun" - sufficient for most English speakers
sen.e: He succeeded Otomaro as the Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and directed the government army, defeating the Ezo army in 801.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")[用語集]

sen.j: 802年に胆沢城、803年に志波城を築いた。
sen.e: He built Isawa Castle in 802 and Shiwa Castle in 803.
He built Isawa Castle in 802 and Shiwa Castle in 803.
He built Isawa Castle in 802 and Shiwa Castle in 803.

sen.j: 810年の薬子の変では平城天皇の脱出を阻止する働きをした。
sen.e: During the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy, Tamuramaro prevented Emperor Heijo's escape.
During the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy of 810, Tamuramaro prevented Emperor Heijo's escape.
During the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy of 810, Tamuramaro prevented Emperor Heijo's escape.

sen.j: 平安時代を通じて優れた武人として尊崇され、後代に様々な伝説を生み、また戦前までは、文の菅原道真と、武の坂上田村麻呂は、文武のシンボル的存在とされた。
sen.e: He was admired as a great warrior throughout the Heian period and became a legendary hero in later periods; before World War II, Michizane SUGAWARA and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro were regarded as representing, respectively, the best literary and military traditions among the Japanese people.

He was admired as a great warrior throughout the Heian period and became a legendary hero in later periods; before World War II, Michizane SUGAWARA and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro were regarded as representing, respectively, the best literary and military traditions among the Japanese people.

He was admired as a great warrior throughout the Heian period and became a legendary hero in later periods; before World War II, Michizane SUGAWARA and SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro were regarded as representing, respectively, the best literary and military traditions among the Japanese people.

sen.j: 父は坂上苅田麻呂で、坂上氏は田村麻呂の祖父の坂上犬養、と苅田麻呂ともに武をもって知られた。
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro's father was SAKANOUE no Karitamaro, whose clan (Sakanoue clan) was celebrated for its military skills, as exemplified by Tamuramaro's grandfather, SAKANOUE no Inukai, and his father Karitamaro himself.

SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro's father was SAKANOUE no Karitamaro of the Sakanoue Clan, which was celebrated for its military skills, as exemplified by Tamuramaro's grandfather, SAKANOUE no Inukai, and his father Karitamaro himself.
sen.cmt: ", whose clan (the Sakanoue clan)"→"of the Sakanoue Clan, which"
sen.e: SAKANOUE no Tamuramaro's father was SAKANOUE no Karitamaro of the Sakanoue Clan, which was celebrated for its military skills, as exemplified by Tamuramaro's grandfather, SAKANOUE no Inukai, and his father Karitamaro himself.

sen.j: 妻は三善清継の娘高子。
sen.e: His wife was MIYOSHI no Takako, Kiyotsugu MIYOSHI's daughter.
His wife was MIYOSHI no Takako, Kiyotsugu MIYOSHI's daughter.
His wife was MIYOSHI no Takako, Kiyotsugu MIYOSHI's daughter.

sen.j: 子に坂上大野、坂上広野、坂上浄野、坂上正野、滋野、継野、継雄、坂上広雄、高雄、高岡、高道、春子がいた。
sen.e: His children included SAKANOUE no Ono, SAKANOUE no Hirono, SAKANOUE no Kiyono, SAKANOUE no Masano, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, SAKANOUE no Hiro, Takao, Takaoka, Takamichi and Haruko.
sen.cmt: 坂上大野→SAKANOUE no Ono (坂上大野)[定訳不明,Wikipedia以外で見つけることができませんでした。]坂上正野→SAKANOUE no Masano (坂上正野)[定訳不明,Wikipedia以外で見つけることができませんでした。]滋野→Shigeno (滋野)[定訳不明,該当する読み方を見つけることができませんでした。]継野→Tsugino (継野)[定訳不明,該当する読み方を見つけることができませんでした。]継雄→Tsuguo (継雄)[定訳不明,該当する読み方を見つけることができませんでした。]坂上広雄→SAKANOUE no Hiro (坂上広雄)[定訳不明,Wikipedia以外で見つけることができませんでした。]高岡→Takaoka (高岡)[定訳不明,該当する読み方を見つけることができませんでした。]
sen.e: His children included SAKANOUE no Ono, SAKANOUE no Hirono, SAKANOUE no Kiyono, SAKANOUE no Masano, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, SAKANOUE no Hiro, Takao, Takaoka, Takamichi and Haruko.
His children included SAKANOUE no Ono, SAKANOUE no Hirono, SAKANOUE no Kiyono, SAKANOUE no Masano, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, SAKANOUE no Hiro, Takao, Takaoka, Takamichi and Haruko.

sen.j: 坂上春子は桓武天皇の妃で葛井親王を産んだ。
sen.e: His daughter, SAKANOUE no Haruko, later became a wife of Emperor Kammu and mother of Prince Kadoi.
His daughter, SAKANOUE no Haruko, later became a wife of Emperor Kammu and mother of Prince Kadoi.
His daughter, SAKANOUE no Haruko, later became a wife of Emperor Kanmu and mother of Prince Kadoi.

sen.j: 滋野、継野、継雄、高雄、高岡は「坂上氏系図」にのみ見え、地方に住んで後世の武士のような字（滋野の「安達五郎」など）を名乗ったことになっており、後世付け加えられた可能性がある。
sen.e: His children, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, Takao and Takaoka appear only in the Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan; they are reported to have lived in places away from Kyoto, calling themselves by family names (such as Goro ADACHI) like samurai in later periods, which leads us to suspect that their names may have been added to the chart afterwards.

His children, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, Takao and Takaoka appear only in the "Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan"; they are reported to have lived in places away from Kyoto, calling themselves by family names (such as Goro ADACHI) like samurai in later periods, which means their names may have been added to the chart afterwards.

His children, Shigeno, Tsugino, Tsuguo, Takao and Takaoka appear only in the 'Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan'; they are reported to have lived in places away from Kyoto, calling themselves by family names (such as 'Goro ADACHI (Shigeno)') like samurai in later periods, which means their names may have been added to the chart afterwards.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'に(Shigeno)補足

sen.j: 子孫は京都にあって明法博士や検非違使大尉に任命された。
sen.e: Tamuramaro's descendents lived in Kyoto and served as legal scholars (myobo hakase) and Kebiishi police officers.
Tamuramaro's descendents lived in Kyoto and served as legal scholars (myobo hakase) and Kebiishi police officers.
Tamuramaro's descendents lived in Kyoto and served as Myobo hakase (teacher of the law in the Ritsuryo system) and Kebiishi police officers.
sen.cmt: 明法博士→Myobo hakase (teacher of the law in the Ritsuryo system)[用語集]

sen.j: 田村麻呂は、天平宝字2年（758年）に坂上苅田麻呂の次男（「坂上氏系図」）または三男（「田邑麻呂伝記」）として生まれた。
sen.e: Tamuramaro was born as the second (according to the Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan) or third (Biography of Tamuramaro) son of SAKANOUE no Karitamaro.
Tamuramaro was born as the second (according to the "Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan") or third ("Biography of Tamuramaro") son of SAKANOUE no Karitamaro.
Tamuramaro was born as the second (according to the 'Genealogical Chart of the Sakanoue Clan') or third ('Biography of Tamuramaro') son of SAKANOUE no Karitamaro in 758.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合わせ"を'に in 758を追加

sen.j: 田村麻呂は近衛府に勤務した。
sen.e: Tamuramaro worked as an officer in the Konoe-fu government office.
Tamuramaro served as an officer in the Imperial Guards.
Tamuramaro served as an officer in the Imperial Guards.

sen.j: 田村麻呂が若年の頃から陸奥国では蝦夷との戦争が激化しており、延暦8年（789年）には紀古佐美の率いる官軍がアテルイの率いる蝦夷軍に大敗した。
sen.e: Ever since Tamuramaro was still in his youth, there had been a raging war with the Ezo people in Mutsu and in 789, the government army led by KI no Kosami was heavily defeated by the Ezo army led by Aterui.
From the time of Tamuramaro's youth, there had been a raging war with the Ezo people in Mutsu and in 789, the government army led by KI no Kosami was heavily defeated by the Ezo army led by Aterui.
sen.cmt: "Ever since Tamuramaro was still in his youth"→"From the time of Tamuramaro's youth"
sen.e: From the time of Tamuramaro's youth, there had been a raging war with the Ezo people in Mutsu Province and in 789, the government army led by KI no Kosami was heavily defeated by the Ezo army led by Aterui.

sen.j: 田村麻呂はその次の征討軍の準備に加わり、延暦11年（791年）に大伴弟麻呂を補佐する征東副使に任じられ、延暦12年（793年）に軍を進発させた。
sen.e: Tamuramaro participated in the preparation for the subsequent military expedition, and upon being appointed as a Vice Commander to assist OTOMO no Otomaro in 791, he embarked on a military expedition.
Tamuramaro participated in the preparations for the next military expedition, and upon being appointed as a Vice Commander to assist OTOMO no Otomaro in 791, he embarked on the military expedition.

Tamuramaro participated in the preparations for the next military expedition, and upon being appointed as a Seito fukushi (Vice Commander) to assist OTOMO no Otomaro in 791, he embarked on the military expedition.
sen.cmt: 征東副使→Seito fukushi (Vice Commander)[用語集]

sen.j: この戦役については『類聚国史』に「征東副将軍坂上大宿禰田村麿已下蝦夷を征す」とだけあり、田村麻呂は四人の副使（副将軍）の一人ながら中心的な役割を果たしたらしい。
sen.e: There is a brief comment about this expedition in Ruiju Kokushi (Book of History) that "Vice Commander SAKANOUE Osukune no Tamuramaro conquered the Ezo army," which leads us to believe that Tamuramaro was playing a leading part in the expedition as one of the four Vice Commanders.

There is a brief comment about this expedition in the "Ruiju Kokushi (Book of History)" that "Vice Commander SAKANOUE Osukune no Tamuramaro conquered the Ezo army," which leads us to believe that Tamuramaro was playing a leading part in the expedition as one of the four Vice Commanders.

There is a brief comment about this expedition in the "Ruiju Kokushi (Book of History)" that 'Vice Commander SAKANOUE Osukune no Tamuramaro conquered the Ezo army,' which leads us to believe that Tamuramaro was playing a leading part in the expedition as one of the four Vice Commanders.

sen.j: 延暦15年（796年）には陸奥按察使、陸奥守、鎮守府将軍を兼任して戦争正面を指揮する官職をすべてあわせ、加えて翌年には征夷大将軍に任じられた。
sen.e: In 796, he was appointed as the Inspector of Mutsu (Mutsu no Azechi), Viceroy of Mutsu and General Commander of the Guardian Army, all at the same time, to be in full command of the army, and in the next year he was also appointed as the Seii-Taishogun (Commander in Chief).

In 796, he was appointed Inspector of Mutsu (Mutsu no Azechi), Governor of Mutsu and Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North), all at the same time, to be in full command of the army, and the following year he was also appointed Seii-Taishogun (Shogun).
sen.cmt: Deleted "as the""Viceroy"→"Governor""General Commander of the Guardian Army"→"Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North)""in the next"→"the following"Deleted "as the""Commander in Chief"→"Shogun"
sen.e: In 796, he was appointed Mutsu no Azechi (Inspector of Mutsu), Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province) and Chinjufu Shogun (Commander-in-Chief of the Defense of the North), all at the same time, to be in full command of the army, and the following year he was also appointed Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians").
sen.cmt: Inspector of Mutsu (Mutsu no Azechi)→Mutsu no Azechi (Inspector of Mutsu)陸奥守→Mutsu no kami (the governor of Mutsu Province)[用語集]征夷大将軍→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")[用語集]

sen.j: 延暦20年（801年）に遠征に出て成功を収め、夷賊（蝦夷）の討伏を報じた。
sen.e: In 801, he set out on a military expedition, which resulted in his victory against the "barbarians (Ezo)."
In 801, he set out on a military expedition, which resulted in his victory against the "barbarians (Ezo)."
In 801, he set out on a military expedition, which resulted in his victory against the barbarians (Ezo).

sen.j: いったん帰京してから翌年、確保した地域に胆沢城を築くために陸奥国に戻り、そこで阿弖利為（阿弖流為）と母礼ら五百余人の降伏を容れた。
sen.e: After returning to Kyoto, he went back to Mutsu in order to build Izawa Castle in the conquered area, accepting the surrender of more than 500 Ezo soldiers, including chief commanders Aterui and More.

After briefly returning to Kyoto, he went back to Mutsu in order to build Izawa Castle in the conquered area, accepting the surrender of more than 500 Ezo soldiers, including chief commanders Aterui and More.

After briefly returning to Kyoto, he went back to Mutsu Province in order to build Izawa Castle in the conquered area, accepting the surrender of more than 500 Ezo soldiers, including chief commanders Aterui and More.

sen.j: 田村麻呂は彼らを許すことを主張したが、都の貴族は反対し、二人を処刑した。
sen.e: Although Tamuramaro insisted on acquitting the two commanders, his proposal was objected to by court nobles in Kyoto and the commanders were executed.
Although Tamuramaro insisted on acquitting the two commanders, his proposal was objected to by court nobles in Kyoto and the commanders were executed.
Although Tamuramaro insisted on acquitting the two commanders, his proposal was objected to by court nobles in Kyoto and the commanders were executed.

sen.j: 延暦22年（803年）には志波城を造った。
sen.e: In 803, he built Shiwa Castle.
In 803, he built Shiwa Castle.
In 803, he built Shiwa Castle.

sen.j: 延暦23年（804年）に再び征夷大将軍に任命され、三度めの遠征を期した。
sen.e: In 804, Tamuramaro was appointed as the Seii-Taishogun once again for the third military expedition to Mutsu.
In 804, Tamuramaro was appointed Shogun once again for the third military expedition to Mutsu.
In 804, Tamuramaro was appointed Seii taishogun once again for the third military expedition to Mutsu.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")[用語集]

sen.j: しかし、延暦23年（804年）に藤原緒嗣が「軍事と造作が民の負担になっている」と論じ、桓武天皇がこの意見を認めたため、征夷は中止になった（徳政相論）。
sen.e: However, in 804, the expedition was cancelled by Emperor Kammu, who accepted FUJIWARA no Otsugu's argument that military expeditions and the construction work for the new capital were placing an intolerable burden on the people (Great Political Debate).

However, that same yea, the expedition was cancelled by Emperor Kammu, who accepted FUJIWARA no Otsugu's argument that military expeditions and the construction work for the new capital were placing an intolerable burden on the people (Great Political Debate).
sen.cmt: "in 804"→"that same year" - although the Japanese has "延暦23年（804年）", it reads strangely so soon after the previous sentence
sen.e: However, that same year, the expedition was cancelled by Emperor Kanmu, who accepted FUJIWARA no Otsugu's argument that military expeditions and the construction work for the new capital were placing an intolerable burden on the people (Great Political Debate).

sen.j: 田村麻呂は活躍の機会を失ったが、本来は臨時職である征夷大将軍の称号をこの後も身に帯び続けた。
sen.e: Although Tamuramaro was no longer able to serve as a military commander, he continued to remain in the post of Seii-Taishogun, which was originally created as an emergency office.
Although Tamuramaro was no longer able to serve as a military commander, he continued to remain in the post of Shogun, which was originally created as an emergency office.
Although Tamuramaro was no longer able to serve as a military commander, he continued to remain in the post of Seii taishogun, which was originally created as an emergency office.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍→seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")[用語集]

sen.j: 戦功によって昇進し、延暦24年（805年）には参議に列した。
sen.e: He was promoted as a result of his military success and in 805, he was allowed to serve as a Councilor.
He was promoted as a result of his military success and in 805, he was allowed to serve as a Councilor.
He was promoted as a result of his military success and in 805, he was allowed to serve as a Sangi (councillor).

sen.j: 大同元年（806年）に中納言、弘仁元年（810年）に大納言になった。
sen.e: He was promoted to Vice Councilor of State in 806 and to Councilor of State in 810.
He was promoted to Vice Councilor of State in 806 and to Councilor of State in 810.
He was promoted to Chunagon (vice-councilor of state) in 806 and to Dainagon (Major Counselor) in 810.
sen.cmt: 中納言→Chunagon (middle counselor)[用語集]大納言→Dainagon (Major Counselor)[用語集]Chunagon (middle counselor)→Chunagon (vice-councilor of state)に変更しました。

sen.j: この間、大同2年（807年）には右近衛大将に任じられた。
sen.e: In 807, he was appointed as the Minister of the Ukon-e Division.
In 807, he was appointed Commander of the Imperial Guards.
sen.cmt: "as the Minister of the Ukon-e Division"→"Commander of the Imperial Guards"
sen.e: In 807, he was appointed Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards).
sen.cmt: 右近衛大将→Ukone no daisho (Major Captain of the Right Division of Inner Palace Guards)[用語集]

sen.j: また、田村麻呂は京都の清水寺を創建したと伝えられる。
sen.e: Tamuramaro is also reported to have constructed Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto.
Tamuramaro is also reported to have constructed Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto.
Tamuramaro is also reported to have constructed Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto.

sen.j: 史実と考えられているが、詳しい事情は様々な伝説があってはっきりしない。
sen.e: While the story is generally accepted as a historical fact, there are many different versions of the story and details remain unclear.
While the story is generally accepted as a historical fact, there are many different versions and the details remain unclear.
While the story is generally accepted as a historical fact, there are many different versions and the details remain unclear.

sen.j: 平城天皇と嵯峨天皇が対立したとき、田村麻呂は上皇によって平城遷都のための造宮使に任じられた。
sen.e: When a conflict arose between Emperor Heijo and Emperor Saga, Tamuramaro was appointed by the Ex-Emperor as a palace construction officer for the transfer of the capital to Heijo.
When a conflict arose between ex-Emperor Heijo and Emperor Saga, Tamuramaro was appointed by the ex-Emperor as a palace construction officer for the transfer of the capital to Heijo.
When a conflict arose between ex-Emperor Heijo and Emperor Saga, Tamuramaro was appointed by the ex-Emperor as a palace construction officer for the transfer of the capital to Heijo.

sen.j: しかし薬子の変では嵯峨天皇についた。
sen.e: However, during the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy, Tamuramaro supported Emperor Saga.
However, during the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy, Tamuramaro supported Emperor Saga.
However, during the Kusuko no Hen Conspiracy, Tamuramaro supported Emperor Saga.

sen.j: 子の坂上広野は近江国の関を封鎖するために派遣され、田村麻呂は美濃道を通って上皇を邀撃する任を与えられた。
sen.e: His son, SAKANOUE no Hirono, was dispatched to Omi in order to block Omi Barrier, while Tamuramaro was ordered to fight back the army of the Ex-Emperor along the Minodo road.
His son, SAKANOUE no Hirono, was dispatched to Omi in order to block Omi Barrier, while Tamuramaro was ordered to attack the army of the ex-Emperor along the Minodo road.
His son, SAKANOUE no Hirono, was dispatched to Omi Province in order to block Omi Barrier, while Tamuramaro was ordered to attack the army of the ex-Emperor along the Minodo road.

sen.j: このとき田村麻呂は、身柄を拘束されていた文室綿麻呂を伴うことを願い、許された。
sen.e: In this incident, Tamuramaro requested for the release of FUNYA no Watamaro, who was kept in custody, and his request was granted.
In this incident, Tamuramaro requested and was granted the release of the captured FUNYA no Watamaro.
sen.cmt: Deleted "for""and his request was granted"→"and was granted" and moved"who was in custody"→"the captured" and moved
sen.e: In this incident, Tamuramaro requested and was granted the release of the captured FUNYA no Watamaro.

sen.j: 平城京から出発した上皇は東国に出て兵を募る予定だったが、大和国添上郡越田村で進路を遮られたことを知り、平城京に戻って出家した。
sen.e: Although the Ex-Emperor intended to organize his army in Togoku (areas east to Kyoto), upon being informed in Koshita Village, Soekami-gun, Yamato, that his way was completely blocked, he returned to Heijokyo and became a priest.

Although the ex-Emperor intended to build an army in the Togoku areas east of Kyoto, upon being informed in Koshita Village, Soekami-gun, Yamato Province, that his way was completely blocked, he returned to Heijokyo (Nara) and became a priest.
sen.cmt: "organize his"→"build an" Added "the"Removed brackets"to"→"of" Added "Province" and "(Nara)"
sen.e: Although the ex-Emperor intended to build an army in the Togoku areas east of Kyoto, upon being informed in Koshita Village, Soekami-gun, Yamato Province, that his way was completely blocked, he returned to Heijokyo (Nara) and became a priest.

sen.j: 田村麻呂は弘仁2年（811年）5月23日に54才で病死した。
sen.e: Tamuramaru died of illness at the age of 54 on May 23, 811.
Tamuramaru died of illness at the age of 54 on May 23, 811.
Tamuramaru died of illness at the age of 54 on June 21, 811.

sen.j: 嵯峨天皇は哀んで一日政務をとらず、田村麻呂をたたえる漢詩を作った。
sen.e: On the day of his death, Emperor Saga refrained from attending to affairs of state in mourning and composed Chinese-style poems in praise of Tamuramaro.
On the day of his death, Emperor Saga refrained from attending to affairs of state in mourning and composed Chinese-style poems in praise of Tamuramaro.
On the day of his death, Emperor Saga refrained from attending to affairs of state in mourning and composed Chinese-style poems in praise of Tamuramaro.

sen.j: 死後従二位を贈られた。
sen.e: He was posthumously awarded the Juni rank.
He was posthumously awarded the Juni (Junior Second) rank.
He was posthumously awarded the Junii (Junior Second Rank).

sen.j: 墓所は、京都市山科区の西野山古墓と推定される。
sen.e: There is an ancient grave in Nishinoyama in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, which is estimated to be his grave.
An ancient grave in Nishinoyama in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, is believed to be his.
sen.cmt: Deleted "There is""which is estimated to be his grave"→"is believed to be his"
sen.e: An ancient grave in Nishinoyama in Yamashina Ward, Kyoto City, is believed to be his.

sen.j: 後世、田村麻呂にまつわる伝説が各地に作られ、しだいに膨らんで歴史上の田村麻呂とかけ離れた人物と筋書きを生んだ。
sen.e: Many stories of Tamuramaro were made in areas across Japan after his death, which were developed into legends and legendary figures that were far removed from the historical Tamuramaro.
After his death, many stories of Tamuramaro were made in areas across Japan, developing into legends and legendary figures that were far removed from the historical Tamuramaro.
After his death, many stories of Tamuramaro were made in areas across Japan, developing into legends and legendary figures that were far removed from the historical Tamuramaro.

sen.j: 伝説中では、田村丸など様々に異なる名をとることがある。
sen.e: In these legends, he appears under a variety of different names, such as Tamuramaru.
In these legends, his name is written in several different ways.
sen.cmt: Reworded sentence to make more sense for English speakers
sen.e: In these legends, his name is written in several different ways.

sen.j: 平安時代の別の高名な将軍藤原利仁の伝説と融合し、両者を同一人と混同したり、父子関係においたりすることもある。
sen.e: Legends about Tamuramaro are also often amalgamated with those about another celebrated Shogun in the Heian period, FUJIWARA no Toshihito, and these two figures are sometimes identified or placed in a father-son relationship.

Legends about Tamuramaro are also often amalgamated with those about another celebrated Shogun in the Heian period, FUJIWARA no Toshihito, with the two sometimes being confused or placed in a father-son relationship.
sen.cmt: "and these two figures are sometimes identified"→"with the two sometimes being confused"
sen.e: Legends about Tamuramaro are also often amalgamated with those about another celebrated Shogun in the Heian period, FUJIWARA no Toshihito, with the two sometimes being confused or placed in a father-son relationship.

sen.j: 伝説中の田村麻呂は蝦夷と戦う武人とは限らず、各地で様々な鬼や盗賊を退治する。
sen.e: In these legends, Tamuramaro is not always a warrior who wages war against barbarians, but a hero who fights off ogres and bandits in various areas.
In these legends, Tamuramaro is not always a warrior who wages war against barbarians, but a hero who fights off oni (ogres) and bandits in various areas.
In these legends, Tamuramaro is not always a warrior who wages war against barbarians, but a hero who fights off oni (ogres) and bandits in various areas.

sen.j: 鎌倉時代には重要な活躍として鈴鹿山の鬼を退治するものが加わった。
sen.e: During the Kamakura period, another important legend version was added to the traditional repertoire, in which Tamuramaro fights off the ogre of Mt. Suzuka.
During the Kamakura period, another important legend was added to the traditional repertoire, in which Tamuramaro fights off the oni of Mt. Suzuka.
During the Kamakura period, another important legend was added to the traditional repertoire, in which Tamuramaro fights off the oni of Mt. Suzuka.

sen.j: 複雑化した話では、田村麻呂は伊勢の鈴鹿山にいた妖術を使う鬼の美女である悪玉（あくたま）と結婚し、その助けを得て悪路王（あくろおう）や大武王（おおたけおう）のような鬼の頭目を陸奥の辺りまで追って討つ（人名と展開は様々である）。
sen.e: In more complex versions, Tamuramaro marries Akutama, an ogre beauty living in Mt. Suzuka in Ise who uses witchcraft, and with her help, fights against ogre leaders named Akuro-O or Otake-O to drive them off to Mutsu (names and details vary).

In more complex versions, Tamuramaro marries Akutama, a beautiful oni living in Mt. Suzuka in Ise who practises witchcraft, and with her help, fights against oni leaders named Akuro-O or Otake-O to drive them off to Mutsu (names and details vary).

In more complex versions, Tamuramaro marries Akutama, a beautiful oni living in Mt. Suzuka in Ise who practises witchcraft, and with her help, fights against oni leaders named Akuro-O or Otake-O to drive them off to Mutsu (names and details vary).

sen.j: 諸々の説話を集成・再構成したものとして、『田村草紙』などの物語、謡曲『田村』、奥浄瑠璃『田村三代記』が作られた。
sen.e: These legends have been collected and reorganized in various forms, such as the story book Tamurazoshi, the Noh song Tamura and the Joruri story Tamura Sandaiki (story about the three generations of the Tamura family).

These legends have been collected and reorganized in various forms, such as the storybook Tamurazoshi, the Noh song Tamura and the Joruri (narrative ballad) Tamura Sandaiki (story about the three generations of the Tamura family).

These legends have been collected and reorganized in various forms, such as the storybook "Tamurazoshi", the Noh song "Tamura" and the Joruri (narrative ballad) "Tamura Sandaiki (story about the three generations of the Tamura family)."
sen.cmt: 原文の『』に合わせ"を補足Italic解除

sen.j: また、江戸時代の『前々太平記』にも収録される。
sen.e: They were also recorded in books published in the Edo period, such as Zen-zen Taiheiki (military story).
They were also recorded in books published in the Edo period, such as the "Zen-zen Taiheiki" military epic.
sen.cmt: Added "the" and inverted comas Deleted brackets"story"→"epic"
sen.e: They were also recorded in books published in the Edo period, such as the "Zen-zen Taiheiki" military epic.

sen.j: 田村麻呂の創建と伝えられる寺社は、岩手県と宮城県を中心に東北地方に多数分布する。
sen.e: There are a number of temples that are believed to have been founded by Tamuramaro scattered in the Tohoku Region, mainly in Iwate and Miyagi Prefectures.
There are a number of temples that are believed to have been founded by Tamuramaro scattered throughout the Tohoku Region, mainly in Iwate and Miyagi Prefectures.
There are a number of temples that are believed to have been founded by Tamuramaro scattered throughout the Tohoku Region, mainly in Iwate and Miyagi Prefectures.

sen.j: 大方は、田村麻呂が観音など特定の神仏の加護で蝦夷征討や鬼退治を果たし、感謝してその寺社を建立したというものである。
sen.e: Most of the stories about these temples tell how Tamuramaro succeeded in fighting off barbarians and ogres with the help of a certain deity (such as the Deity of Mercy) and how he founded these temples to express his gratitude.

Most of the stories about these temples tell how Tamuramaro succeeded in fighting off barbarians and oni with the help of certain deities (such as the Deity of Mercy) and how he founded these temples to express his gratitude.

Most of the stories about these temples tell how Tamuramaro succeeded in fighting off barbarians and oni with the help of certain deities (such as the Deity of Mercy) and how he founded these temples to express his gratitude.

sen.j: 伝承は田村麻呂が行ったと思われない地にも分布する。
sen.e: Legends are found even in areas that are unlikely to have been visited by Tamuramaro.
Legends are found even in areas that are unlikely to have been visited by Tamuramaro.
Legends are found even in areas that are unlikely to have been visited by Tamuramaro.

sen.j: 京都市の清水寺を除いてほとんどすべてが後世の付託と考えられる。
sen.e: Except for the legend about Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto City, most of these legends are probably fictional stories created in later periods.
Except for the legend about Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto City, most of these legends are probably fictional stories created in later periods.
Except for the legend about Kiyomizu-dera Temple in Kyoto City, most of these legends are probably fictional stories created in later periods.

sen.j: その他、田村麻呂が見つけた温泉、田村麻呂が休んだ石など様々に付会した物や地が多い。
sen.e: There are also hot springs that are believed to have been discovered by Tamuramaro and even stones that Tamuramaru is believed to have sat on.
There are also hot springs that are believed to have been discovered by Tamuramaro and even stones that Tamuramaru is believed to have sat on.
There are also hot springs that are believed to have been discovered by Tamuramaro and even stones that Tamuramaru is believed to have sat on.

sen.j: 長野県の清水寺には、田村麻呂が奉納したと伝えられる鍬形（重要文化財）がある。
sen.e: in Seisui-ji Temple in Nagano Prefecture, there is a helmet crest (important cultural property) that is believed to have been dedicated by Tamuramaro.
In Seisui-ji Temple in Nagano Prefecture, there is a helmet crest (an important cultural property) that is believed to have been presented by Tamuramaro.
In Seisui-ji Temple in Nagano Prefecture, there is a helmet crest (an important cultural property) that is believed to have been presented by Tamuramaro.
